PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions herein will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If there are insufficient sheets of paper, or if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, please write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1905, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Plat: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Have?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ). One will be sent to you and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the questionnaires:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, or you may worry about leaving blank spaces. If so, it is better to give details, or describe the particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did Saskatchewan Pioneers Think?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would like to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

All questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed Questionnaire to:

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
I was working on a railway line in France when I decided to join the army. I had been working there for about six months when I joined up. I was assigned to the 4th Battalion and served in France until July 1919.
I wrote to my father on our last letter when I wrote from a town in the north of England. I wrote them in our own handwriting and signed them. My father, I am sure, would have been very pleased with me. He was very fond of his children and had a great deal of affection for us.

Incidentally, I must say that I have been very busy lately, working on a new project which I believe will be successful. I am confident that it will be a great success.

I am writing this letter to you now because I want you to know how much I appreciate your support and encouragement. You have always been there for me, and I am grateful for that.

I hope you are well and that everything is going well for you. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
And here they are in our own country.

My father, brothers and I have been living there for years. We have cattle, sheep, and other animals. Occasionally, we help our neighbors by giving them some of our produce.

We have lived here for many years now, and we are very happy with our lives.

I joined the army in May 1915 and served in France until July 1919. I was promoted to Captain and received a medal for my service.

Relieved July 1919.
Led concrete work on railroad tracks. Worked out to pay for our christening. When I worked for a man at Safey Hill, I took a pair of three-year-old steers and broke them in as soon as morning. Lazarus and Job. My father, brothers and I traveled from Safey Hill to our present location driving 18 head of cattle, 3 colts, incidentally killed breaking in oxen on the road. Worked 2 summers on goat wood and teams near Karnsack.

Joined army May 1915. 44th Battalion. Served in Bas., England, Belgium and France. Returned July 1919.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?  
Occasionally answered all letters.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.  
Married Myla Taylor, Dec. 23, 1923

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?  
Yes, I'd met my family including my mother and younger children.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.  
The following year - all except the exception of my eldest older brother settled on sections 13 and 14.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?  
Our first dwelling place was a tent. For our stock we had a 4-room tent. Our second house was made of poles, with hay for a roof and sod floor. By the time my mother came (the following year) we had a 4-roomed log house. The next year we purchased - built a lumber house (for) we purchased - bought a lumber house (for) used a horse team and paid for the saving by working on the mill.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?  
Groceries from Denio and Fort Riley. 36, 28 Mission in the district of Emmelle. Mar. 5-20 Occasionally drove to Emmelle - used a good driving team. Went to the occasional dance.
3. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Occasionally

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married to Mr. Taylor, Dec. 25, 1923

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes, my family including my mother and father settled in the area.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

The following year - all arrived in Saskatchewan, 1873 and 1874.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Our first winter was very hard, with heavy snow and cold weather. We had to rely on the land for our needs. The weather was harsh, but we persevered and found ways to survive.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

Occasionally and rarely. Used a horse drawn team to travel.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   During World War I while we were in the army post.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Bought mine in 1920 - touring Ford - 1 man top. Half starter $7000

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Benita - 36 miles
   Fort Pelly - 28 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We still trade at Pelly and Norway, unless we happen to be in Harrack.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Every three months

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   In the mid-twenties

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Have always bought more or less by mail order. However, the bulk of our purchases were and are still made at the local towns. Traveling buying is now almost a thing of the past. Buying by catalogue buying is dying out.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Never

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   We had our minds made up to stay here when we first came. We saw visions and dreamed dreams, those days of a wheat empire.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920's? Did many return?

A few moved to the States and did not return, but many came from the States back and remained.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
